For industrial production of HMB, Pt-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol is a potent synthetic method. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Aerobic oxidation Pt-Bi NPs Metal oxides Alcohols Carboxylic acids 1 Introduction A metabolite of leucine, β-Hydroxy β-methylbutyric acid (HMB), is expected as a promising therapeutic agent or a supplement. For industrial production of HMB, Pt-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol is a potent synthetic method. However, the previous report using Pt-Bi catalyst supported on active carbon suffered from low tolerance to high substrate concentration conditions, which leads to low volumetric productivity. Herein, we report aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol using Pt-Bi catalysts supported on ZrO2 or TiO2, showing high tolerance to the high substrate concentration conditions. In addition, these catalysts exhibited high recyclability. Scanning transmission electron microscopy analyses suggested the Pt-Bi species supported on ZrO2 or TiO2 are less likely to aggregate than those supported on activated carbon. Additionally, these metal oxides supported Pt-Bi catalysts showed lower metal leaching than the carbon supported catalysts. Besides, the results of the various control experiments indicated the prevention of dehydration of an aldehyde intermediate is important for further improvement. HMB has received considerable attention because of the effect of suppressing muscle loss [1] and is expected as a promising therapeutic agent preventing muscle breakdown [2,3] or as a supplement for muscle building [4]. Various industrial synthetic methods of HMB have been developed such as oxidation of diacetone alcohol with iodine followed by base hydrolysis [5], oxidation of diacetone alcohol with sodium hypochlorite [6], base hydrolysis of 4,4-dimethyloxetane-2-one [7], and 1,2-addition of activated acetyl compounds to acetone using biocatalysts ( Scheme 1a–d)[8]. Among them, the aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol (IPG), which is one of the chemical feedstocks, using a supported metal catalyst is a potent synthetic method of HMB because the reaction utilizes molecular oxygen in the air as a sole oxidant and produces only water as a byproduct (Scheme 1e). Supported metal nanoparticle catalysts such as Pt, Pd, and Au have been generally employed for the oxidation of alcohols by O2 gas or air [9–12]. In particular, Pt or Pt-Bi catalysts are superior in that the reaction proceeds without bases and activated carbon-supported Pt-Bi catalysts were also employed for the aerobic oxidation of IPG in a patent [13]. However, there exist several issues that remain to be solved. For example, activated carbon-supported Pt catalysts generally have low reusability when used in the aerobic oxidation of alcohols [14]. In addition, various side reactions such as acetalization of the aldehyde intermediate with IPG and dehydration of aldehyde intermediate or HMB would potentially proceed under the reaction conditions for aerobic oxidation of IPG. Nevertheless, the details of the reaction path have remained unexplored. Furthermore, performing the reaction at a higher substrate concentration is desirable since the volumetric productivity is important in terms of the efficiency of the industrial processes while high substrate concentration increases byproducts and decreases selectivity for carboxylic acids in aerobic oxidation of alcohols with a metal catalyst [15]. However, the effect of substrate concentration in aerobic oxidation of alcohols with heterogeneous catalysts has not been investigated enough. Moreover, HMB has high water solubility and requires a lot of energy to purify the product from water. Taking these issues into consideration, the mechanistic investigation of aerobic oxidation of IPG and the development of new heterogeneous Pt catalysts having high activity and recyclability at high substrate concentrations are important goals from the viewpoint of green chemistry. Our group has been dedicated to the development of reactions with transition-metal nanoparticles (NPs) catalysts supported on metal oxides [16]. The metal-support interactions in the heterogeneous catalysts often affect the catalytic activity, selectivity, and reusability. Hence, metal oxide supports have recently gathered much attention as a handle for improving catalytic performances [17]. We envisioned that the use of appropriate metal oxide supports has an influence on the catalysis, which leads to improving the catalyst recyclability and the tolerance to the high substrate concentration conditions. Herein, we report that Pt-Bi nanoparticles catalysts supported on monoclinic ZrO2 or rutile TiO2 show high activity and recyclability in the aerobic oxidation of IPG in conjunction with the effect of the substrate concentrations. In addition, the results of several control experiments revealed the reaction pathways for side reactions of intermediates and byproducts. 2 Experimental 2.1 General procedure for the preparation of supported Pt-Bi catalyst For the catalyst preparation, ZrO2 (JRC-ZRO-8, monoclinic) provided by Catalysis Society of Japan, TiO2 (rutile) purchased from FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation, SiO2(Q-10) purchased from FUJI SILYSIA CHEMICAL LTD, Al2O3 purchased from STREM CHEMICALS, Inc. were used. The metal oxide support (MO x , 969.3 mg) was impregnated with the aqueous solution of H2PtCl6 (1 mL, 20 g/L of Pt) under air, and the resulting mixture was heated at 40 °C with stirring until the solvent evaporated to form a powder. After that, the mixture was dried at 120 °C overnight, then calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h to give the powder of calcined Pt/MO x . The temperature in the calcination process was raised at a speed of 6.25 °C/min. Bi(NO3)3‧5 H2O (24.9 mg, 0.5 eq to Pt) was dissolved in HNO3 aq (1 mol/L, 1 mL), and added to the calcined Pt/MO x . The resulting mixture was heated at 40 °C with stirring until the solvent evaporated to form a powder. After that, the sample was dried at 120 °C overnight. The resultant powder was reduced with H2 flow (20 mL/min) at 350 °C for 4 h to provide 2 wt% Pt-Bi/MO x . The temperature in the reduction process was raised at a speed of 7.8 °C /min. After the reduction, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature. H2 gas was replaced with N2 gas before opening the oven. In the case of the carbon-supported catalyst, the activated carbon (Maxsorb MSC-30, 969.3 mg) was impregnated with the solution of Bi(NO3)3‧5 H2O (24.9 mg, 0.5 eq to Pt) in HNO3 aq. (5 mL) and heated at 40 °C with stirring until the solvent evaporated to form a powder. After that, the mixture was dried at 120 °C overnight then impregnated with the aqueous solution of Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2 (5 mL, 7.94 g/L). The resulting mixture was heated at 40 °C with stirring until the solvent evaporated to form a powder. Then, the sample was dried at 120 °C overnight. The resultant powder was reduced with H2 flow (20 mL/min) at 350 °C for 4 h to provide 2 wt% Pt-Bi/C. The temperature in the reduction process was raised at a speed of 7.8 °C /min. After the reduction, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature. H2 gas was replaced with N2 gas before opening the oven. Note that the Pt loading was fixed at 2 wt% unless otherwise stated. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Particle sizes of Pt-Bi NPs were determined by the combination of bright-field scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) images and CO-pulse adsorption measurements. STEM and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were performed using a JEOL JEM-ARM200F microscope operated at 200 kV. CO-pulse adsorption of the samples was performed using BELCAT-B (MicrotracBEL, Osaka, Japan). Each sample was first heated to 373 K and the temperature was kept for 25 min, then subjected to oxidation under a O2 flow (50 mL/min) at 473 K for 15 min, and then cooled to 323 K. Subsequently, the sample was reduced under H2 flow (50 mL/min) at 323 K for 15 min. The amount of CO adsorption by Pt atoms in the catalysts was evaluated by the quantitative pulsed injection of molecular CO to the reduced catalyst. The calculated size of the NPs based on the equation d (nm) = 1.13/D [18], and the CO adsorption of supports was not excluded. A CO/Pt adsorption stoichiometry was assumed to be 1/1 when calculating the Pt dispersion and particle size of the metal NPs. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses of the catalysts were conducted on a Rigaku MiniFlex600 equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. Agilent 4100 microwave plasma atomic emission spectrometer (MP-AES) was used to evaluate the metal leaching of the catalyst samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using PHI Quantera SXM equipped with an Al Kα radiation source at a pressure below 10−6 Pa order. The obtained binding energies were calibrated to the C1s peak at 284.8 eV [19]. XPS profiles were further analyzed using XPSPEAK41 software. 2.3 Optimization of reaction conditions The Pt-Bi catalyst (0.5 mol% as Pt) and an aqueous solution of IPG (1.0 mmol, 10 wt% aq) were put into a 40 mL autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar. The autoclave was filled with 0.9 MPa of air and heated to 80 °C. The reaction system contains approximately 3 equivalents of oxygen (3.05 mmol), and additional oxygen was not charged during the reaction. The reaction mixture was stirred at 800 rpm for 5 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to 0 °C in an ice bath. Then, the reaction mixture was diluted with methanol and transferred to a screw vial. The screw vial was centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. Methanol was added to the screw vial with the remaining catalyst, centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. These processes were repeated three times, and all the supernatants were combined. To the resultant mixture was added diglyme (32.8 mg) as an internal standard for GC analysis. The mixture was analyzed by GC. After being concentrated under reduced pressure, the concentrated mixture was then analyzed by 1H NMR using 2-methoxynaphtalene as an internal standard. 2.4 Experiments for tolerance to IPG concentrations The Pt-Bi catalyst (0.5 mol% Pt), an aqueous solution of IPG (1.0 mmol of 10 wt% aq, 2.0 mmol of 20 wt% aq, 3.0 mmol of 30 wt% aq, or 5.0 mmol of 50 wt% aq) were put into a 40 mL autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar. The autoclave was connected to a 200 mL autoclave, and the volume of the system was adjusted by adding the water to keep the same O2 equivalent. The autoclaves were filled with 0.9 MPa of air and heated to 80 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 900 rpm for 12 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to 0 °C in an ice bath. Then, the reaction mixture was diluted with methanol and transferred to a screw vial. The screw vial was centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. Methanol was added to the screw vial with the remaining catalyst, centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. These processes were repeated three times, and all the supernatants were combined. To the resultant mixture was added diglyme (32.8 mg) as an internal standard for GC analysis. The mixture was analyzed by GC. After being concentrated under reduced pressure, the concentrated mixture was then analyzed by 1H NMR using 2-methoxynaphtalene as an internal standard. 2.5 Catalyst recycle experiment The Pt-Bi catalyst (0.5 mol% Pt) and an aqueous solution of IPG (2.0 mmol, 20 wt%) were put into a 40 mL autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar. The autoclave was filled with 0.9 MPa of air and heated to 80 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 900 rpm for 12 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to 0 °C in an ice bath. Then, the reaction mixture was diluted with methanol and transferred to a screw vial. The screw vial was centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. Methanol was added to the screw vial with the remaining catalyst, centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. These processes were repeated three times, and all the supernatants were combined. To the resultant mixture was added diglyme (32.8 mg) as an internal standard for GC analysis. The mixture was analyzed by GC. After being concentrated under reduced pressure, the concentrated mixture was then analyzed by 1H NMR using 2-methoxynaphtalene as an internal standard. The recovered catalyst was dried under reduced pressure, then reused in the next recycle experiment on the same scale. The reused catalysts were characterized by TEM and MP-AES after reusing five times. In the case of Pt-Bi/ZrO2, XPS analysis of the reused catalyst were also carried out. 2.6 Substrate scope The Pt-Bi catalyst (0.5 mol% as Pt) and alcohol dissolved in H2O/t-BuOH= 67/33 vol% mixture (1.0 mmol, 10 wt%) were put into a 40 mL autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer bar. The autoclave was filled with 0.9 MPa of air and heated to 80 °C. The reaction mixture was stirred at 1200 rpm for 20 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to 0 °C in an ice bath. Then, the reaction mixture was diluted with methanol and transferred to a screw vial. The screw vial was centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. Methanol was added to the screw vial with the remaining catalyst, centrifuged, and the supernatant was collected. These processes were repeated three times, and all the supernatants were combined. To the resultant mixture was added diglyme (32.8 mg) as an internal standard for GC analysis. The mixture was analyzed by GC. After being concentrated under reduced pressure, the concentrated mixture was then analyzed by 1H NMR using 2-methoxynaphtalene as an internal standard. 3 Results and discussion We initially screened Pt-Bi NPs catalysts supported on various metal oxides in the aerobic oxidation of IPG ( Table 1). The catalyst supported on activated carbon gave HMB in 53 % yield (entry 1). The catalysts supported on SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 gave HMB in low yields (21 % and 25 %, respectively, entries 2 and 3). The catalyst supported on rutile TiO2 (Pt-Bi/TiO2) gave HMB in high yield (77 %, entry 4). The catalyst supported on monoclinic ZrO2 (Pt-Bi/ZrO2) also gave HMB in high yield (67 %, entry 5). Next, we investigated the effect of the Pt:Bi ratio. The HMB yield using Pt-Bi/ZrO2 with a Pt:Bi molar ratio of 1:1, 4:1, or Pt/ZrO2 were slightly lower than that of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 with a Pt:Bi molar ratio of 2:1 (51 %, 58 % and 55 %, respectively, entries 6–8). Furthermore, in order to investigate the activity of the catalysts, initial conversion rates with Pt-Bi/ZrO2, Pt-Bi/TiO2, Pt-Bi/C, and Pt/ZrO2 were explored, and the performances with these catalysts were similar to each other (entries 9–12). In addition, we also examined the reactions at the 30 wt% substrate concentration conditions to investigate the effect of the substrate concentration on the activity of the catalysts. The substrate concentration with the Pt-Bi catalysts affected the initial rate of the reaction (entries 13–15). The higher the substrate concentration, the slower the initial reaction rate. Commonly, water could initially assist the dissociation of molecular oxygen into hydroxy groups in the aerobic oxidation of alcohols, and the function would affect the initial conversion rate[20]. Based on these results, the catalysts supported on ZrO2, or TiO2 with a Pt:Bi molar ratio of 2:1 were selected as the suitable catalyst. To investigate the structures of the Pt and Bi species supported on the catalysts, XRD analysis of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2, Pt-Bi/TiO2, and Pt-Bi/C with a Pt:Bi molar ratio of 2:1 were performed. However, peaks assignable to the Pt and Bi species were not observed in the XRD results of the above Pt-Bi catalysts, suggesting that Pt and Bi species were well dispersed on the supports (See the Supplementary data). Next, the average size of particles supported on ZrO2, TiO2, and C were measured in two ways. The particle sizes measured using the BF-STEM images of these catalysts were 2.2 ± 1.0 nm (Pt-Bi/ZrO2, Figs. 1a), 2.1 ± 0.9 nm (Pt-Bi/TiO2, Fig. 1b), and 1.4 ± 0.4 nm (Pt-Bi/C, Fig. 1c), while the average particle sizes analyzed by CO-pulse adsorption were 4.4 nm (Pt-Bi/ZrO2), 11.2 nm (Pt-Bi/TiO2), and 5.8 nm (Pt-Bi/C) ( Table 2). Particle sizes based on CO-pulse data are larger than those based on TEM images, indicating that both Pt and Bi species are exposed on the surface of the NPs. Considering these results, the surface Pt/Bi ratios of the catalysts would be similar to those of the metal compositions in catalyst preparations [21]. To obtain further structural insights of the Pt and Bi species in the catalysts, EDS analysis was performed. The EDS analysis of Pt-Bi/ZrO2 showed that both Pt and Bi were uniformly dispersed ( Fig. 2). In addition, EDS line analysis of the metal nanoparticle as small as 10 nm suggested that Pt and Bi species exist in the same place while the analysis of small metal nanoparticles was difficult due to low spatial resolution of EDS line analysis. Furthermore, the EDS analysis of Pt-Bi/TiO2 showed the similar result ( Fig. 3). These results indicate that the supported metal nanoparticles were a mixture of Pt and Bi species. With the optimum catalyst in hand, we next investigated the effect of the concentration of IPG aqueous solution in the oxidation. To investigate the effect of the substrate concentration on the selectivity and yield, we performed oxidation of IPG at several substrate concentrations with Pt-Bi/ZrO2, Pt-Bi/TiO2, or Pt-Bi/C catalyst ( Fig. 4). In the oxidation using Pt-Bi/C catalyst, the yield of HMB decreased as the concentration of IPG solution increased from 10 wt% to 20, 30, and 50 wt%, and the amount of acetal 4a increased instead. In contrast, the highest HMB yields in the oxidation using Pt-Bi/ZrO2 or Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts (Pt-Bi/ZrO2:77%, Pt-Bi/TiO2:76%) were observed when the concentration of the IPG aqueous solution was 20 wt%. Additionally, the reactions with these catalysts in 30 wt% and 50 wt% concentration showed a higher yield of HMB and lower yields of acetal 4a than the reactions with the Pt-Bi/C catalyst in the same concentration. The higher the concentration of the reaction solution, the more acetal 4a was produced. These results show that Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 oxidize aldehyde 3a to HMB faster than Pt-Bi/C and/or the formation of acetal 4a by Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 is slower than that by Pt-Bi/C. This is assumed to be owing to the difference in polarity of the support surface, with the metal oxide support having a higher affinity for water and substrate than the activated carbon support. In contrast, the activated carbon support has a large volume due to its low bulk density and adsorbs the solution, causing the stirring efficiency is likely to decrease. To assess the recyclability of the Pt-Bi catalysts, we conducted recycle experiments ( Fig. 5). In the reactions with the Pt-Bi/C catalyst, the yield of HMB and the conversion of IPG had decreased as the number of catalyst reuses increased while the yield of acetal 4a had increased. In contrast, in the reaction with Pt-Bi/ZrO2 or Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalyst, the yield of HMB had kept 60–80 %, the conversion of IPG had kept over 90 %, and the yield of acetal 4a had not increased. These results suggested Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 have higher recyclability than Pt-Bi/C. To probe the origin of high recyclability of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and TiO2, we then investigated the particle sizes of the supported metal nanoparticles after the recycling experiments using BF-STEM (Fig. 1). In the fresh Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts, the supported metal NPs were uniformly distributed with an average particle size of 2.2 and 2.1 nm, respectively while the average particle size of the fresh Pt-Bi/C catalyst was 1.4 nm, the value of which is smaller than that of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and the Pt-Bi/TiO2. Regarding the investigation of the used catalysts, analyses were performed after six-time reused samples, and aggregation of the metal nanoparticles were observed. The average particle sizes of the used Pt-Bi/MO x catalysts in BF-STEM images were 6.8 ± 3.9 nm (Pt-Bi/ZrO2), and 4.0 ± 2.0 nm (Pt-Bi/TiO2). In contrast, the metal NPs of Pt-Bi/C showed a bimodal distribution with the average particle size of 3.2 ± 3.0 nm and 48.2 ± 14.1 nm for the small and large NPs, respectively. These results suggest that the high recyclability of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and TiO2 catalysts be attributable to the strong interactions between the metal NPs and metal oxide supports. To reveal the origin of the difference in the catalyst recyclability, we investigated the leaching of the Pt and Bi species on the Pt-Bi/ZrO2, Pt-Bi/TiO2, and Pt-Bi/C catalysts ( Table 3). Both Pt and Bi species of Pt-Bi/ZrO2 were not considerably decreased after the reaction. Regarding the Pt-Bi/TiO2, little leaching of Pt species was observed while Bi species were lost by half after the reaction. In contrast to Pt-Bi catalysts supported on the metal oxides, Pt-Bi/C lost more than half of the Pt species as well as Bi species after the reaction. These results suggested that serious leaching of Pt and Bi species from Pt-Bi/C resulted in the decrease in catalytic activity observed in the recycling experiments (Fig. 5). These results suggest that the high recyclability of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and TiO2 catalysts is partially due to the low sintering property of Pt-Bi bimetallic NPs attributable to the strong interactions between the metal NPs and metal oxide supports. Considering the results of the leaching experiments, we used Pt-Bi/ZrO2 for further investigations. The effects of Bi and ZrO2 on the activity and selectivity of the IPG oxidation were investigated ( Table 4). The oxidation with a Bi-free Pt/ZrO2 catalyst showed a lower HMB yield (49 %) than the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst (Table 4, entry 2). On the other hand, no HMB was formed when Bi/ZrO2 or ZrO2 was used as a catalyst (Table 4, entries 3 and 4). These results indicated that Pt is essential for the activity and Bi species improved the product selectivity. We then investigated the oxidation state of the Pt and Bi species of the fresh and six-time reused Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalysts using XPS ( Fig. 6). Pt 4 f spectra of the fresh Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst showed main peaks at binding energies of 70.8 eV (Pt 4 f7/2) and 74.1 eV (Pt 4 f5/2), suggesting that Pt species of the catalyst were primarily in the Pt(0) state (Fig. 6a). Additionally, peaks attributed to Pt(2 +) (72.2 eV, Pt 4 f7/2, 75.5 eV, Pt 4 f5/2) and Pt(4 +) (74.1 eV, Pt 4 f7/2, 77.4 eV, Pt 4 f5/2) are also observed [22]. From the area ratio of these peaks, the molar ratio of Pt(0), Pt(2 +), and Pt(4 +) species on the fresh Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst was found to be 76:18:6. As for the XPS spectra of the recovered Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst after used six times, pairs of peaks assigned to the Pt(0), Pt(2 +), and Pt(4 +) species were observed at 70.6 eV (Pt 4 f7/2) and 73.8 eV (Pt 4 f5/2), 72.1 eV (4 f7/2) and 75.3 eV (4 f5/2), and 73.9 eV (4 f7/2) and 77.1 eV (4 f5/2), respectively. In comparison with the XPS spectra for the fresh Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst, Pt(0) area ratio was decreased by 6% and the area ratio of Pt(2 +) and Pt(4 +) was increased (Fig. 6c). On the other hand, Bi 4 f spectra of the fresh catalyst showed pairs of peaks at binding energies of 156.9 eV (Bi 4 f7/2) and 162.2 eV (Bi 4 f5/2), 159.1 eV (Bi 4 f7/2) and 167.4 eV (Bi 4 f5/2), which were attributable to Bi(0) and Bi(3 +), respectively in a molar ratio of 39:61 (Fig. 6b) [23]. Peaks of the Bi(0) and Bi(3 +) species were also observed at the binding energies of 156.9 eV (Bi 4 f7/2), 162.2 eV (Bi 4 f5/2), 159.0 eV (Bi2 4 f7/2), and 167.3 eV (Bi 4 f5/2) for the Bi 4 f spectra of the used Pt-Bi/ZrO2. The molar ratio of Bi(0):Bi(3 +) was changed from 39:61–17:83 (Fig. 6d). Considering that Pt(2 +) and Pt(4 +) are unlikely to be active species in aerobic oxidation of alcohols[24], one of the roles of Bi species is presumably to suppress the deactivation of Pt(0) by having Bi(0) oxidized instead of Pt(0) [21–25]. Oxidation of IPG to HMB includes the aldehyde oxidation step, which potentially proceeds in the absence of catalysts [26]. To investigate the effects of the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst in the oxidation of aldehyde 3a, the control experiments were performed using aldehyde 3a as the substrate ( Scheme 2). An aqueous solution of aldehyde 3a (10 wt%) was subjected to the standard reaction conditions. Aldehyde 3a was converted almost completely and provided HMB in a 50 % yield (entry 1). The reaction in the absence of Pt-Bi/ZrO2 showed 94 % conversion of 3a and 57% yield of HMB (entry 2). Notably, in the presence of the catalyst, 4a was the major by-product, which can be reversibly converted to 3a, whereas in the absence of the catalyst, dehydrated 5a was obtained. As discussed later, 5a hardly convert to 3a, which leads to lower yields. These results suggest that the catalytic activity and selectivity in the oxidation of 3a needs to be improved to increase the yield. To investigate the reaction pathways of the aerobic oxidation of IPG via Pt-Bi/ZrO2 catalyst, control experiments related to the stability of carboxylic acids 2a (HMB), 6a, and aldehydes 5a under the reaction conditions was examined ( Scheme 3). To conduct the experiments under reaction conditions where the aerobic oxidation of alcohol proceeds, the control experiments were carried out in the presence of butanol (1b), and butanoic acid was confirmed to be formed in each of the experiments. Scheme 3a shows the control experiment with HMB (2a). Under the reaction conditions, 2a was converted in 11% and produced dehydrated product 6a in 0.5 % yield, suggesting that 2a has acceptable stability under the standard reaction conditions. In Scheme 3b, the conjugated aldehyde 5a was converted by 88 % to provide the corresponding carboxylic acid 6a in 30 % yield and 2a was not observed at all. These results suggest that hydration of the conjugated aldehyde 5a or carboxylic acid 6a does not occur. In the reaction of the conjugated carboxylic acid 6a, 6a was hardly consumed under the reaction conditions (Scheme 3c). The results shown in Scheme 3 indicated almost all of 6a was produced from 5a, and decarboxylation of HMB and 6a virtually did not proceed. To examine the possibility of decarboxylation, the amount of carbon dioxide in the reactions of 5a or 6a was evaluated by gas analysis (See the Supplementary data). Only a small amount of carbon dioxide (less than 5 %) was observed under the reaction conditions (Scheme 3b and c). The time course of the reaction and the product distribution was further investigated ( Fig. 7). The yield of HMB (2a) had increased up to 10 h and remained at that yield until the end of the reaction. The yields of the aldehyde intermediate 3a and acetal 4a reached a maximum at 1 h after starting the reaction and then decreased. The dehydrated conjugated carbonyl compounds, 5a and 6a remained in very low amounts (< 5 %) throughout the reaction. These results showed the formation of HMB (2a) proceeds via aldehyde 3a, with the reversible generation of acetal 4a. Based on the mechanistic studies, the reaction path is summarized in Scheme 4. First, IPG (1a) was oxidized to 3a by Pt-Bi catalyzed processes. Then, the aldehyde 3a was oxidized into HMB (2a) with or without the Pt-Bi catalyst. During the reaction pathway, acetal 4a was generated from IPG and aldehyde 3a as a resting state. In addition, a small amount of conjugated aldehyde 5a was also produced by the dehydration of aldehyde 3a, followed by further oxidation to form conjugated carboxylic acid 6a. The scope of alcohol substrates was investigated ( Scheme 5). Aliphatic primary alcohols gave carboxylic acids in good yields (2b–2e 68–94 %). Benzyl alcohol needed twice the amount of catalyst and gave benzoic acid in good yield (2 h 84 %). However, allylic alcohols gave conjugated carboxylic acid in low yields (2 g 44 %, 2i 0.8 %), but afforded aldehyde 3i in good yield (68 %) in a shorter reaction time (5 h). Diol 1j did not give hydroxy acid 2j; however, lactone 2j' was obtained instead (46 %). 4 Conclusions In summary, we reported the aerobic oxidation of IPG using Pt-Bi NPs catalysts supported on ZrO2 or TiO2. These catalytic systems provide HMB (2a) with up to 77% yields with higher catalyst reusability and tolerance to high substrate concentration conditions than the catalyst supported on the active carbon. It is worthy of note that aerobic oxidation under high substrate concentration conditions is of great importance in industrial applications from a productivity standpoint, but few studies have focused on developing reactions at high substrate concentrations. The present study is a good starting point for future development of highly efficient catalytic aerobic oxidation. The detailed characterization of the catalysts revealed that the Pt-Bi/ZrO2 and the Pt-Bi/TiO2 catalysts exhibited less aggregation and leaching of Pt than the Pt-Bi/C catalyst in the oxidation. These differences may have brought higher yields of HMB and better catalyst recycling. In addition, the mechanistic investigations including control experiments showed the reasonable reaction path from IPG to HMB and emerged the issues of the low selectivity in the oxidation of the aldehyde 3a. These insights clearly suggested the next research guide for further catalyst development. CRediT authorship contribution statement Yasutaka Kawai: Investigation, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: β-Hydroxy β-methylbutyric acid (HMB) is expected as a promising therapeutic agent or a supplement. For industrial production of HMB, Pt-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol is a potent synthetic method. However, the previous report using Pt-Bi catalyst supported on active carbon suffered from low tolerance to high substrate concentration conditions, which leads to low volumetric productivity. Herein, we report aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol using Pt-Bi catalysts supported on ZrO2 or TiO2, showing high tolerance to the high substrate concentration conditions. In addition, these catalysts exhibited high recyclability. Scanning transmission electron microscopy analyses suggested the Pt-Bi species supported on ZrO2 or TiO2 are less likely to aggregate than those supported on activated carbon. Additionally, these metal oxides supported catalysts showed lower metal leaching than the carbon supported catalysts. Besides, the results of the various control experiments indicated the prevention of dehydration of an aldehyde intermediate is important for further improvement.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of isoprene glycol with platinum-bismuth nanoparticles catalysts supported on metal oxides
